awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Process Systems Framework for the Efficient Design, Intensification and Control of Modular Energy Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Lima, Fernando 
Proposal Number: 1653098 
Institution: West Virginia University Research Corporation
Title: CAREER: Process Systems Framework for the Efficient Design, Intensification and Control of Modular Energy Systems

This project aims to develop an optimization-based framework for the design and control of modular energy systems. The work is inspired by the current abundance of shale gas and its potential for use as a low-cost feedstock for producing energy and chemicals. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed approaches, two natural gas utilization case studies will be addressed: (i) a membrane reactor for direct conversion of methane to fuels and chemicals; and (ii) a natural gas combined cycle system for combined heat and power generation. The successful completion of the proposed research will provide a framework to facilitate the penetration of modular systems into the economy. The main educational and outreach goal of the proposal is to enable experiential learning by employing an interactive gaming environment of 3-D process simulators. To achieve this goal, the following activities are proposed: (i) incorporation of interactive simulator learning tools into undergraduate and graduate chemical engineering courses that include process systems concepts; and (ii) implementation of simulator-based gaming activities for outreach events focused on learning, exploration and recruitment. These activities will be designed to engage high-school and undergraduate students, including underrepresented groups, the lay public, and process systems researchers.

The proposed research will provide theoretical advances in process design, control and estimation. Two research directions are proposed: (i) a nonlinear optimization-based approach for process design and intensification that employs computational geometry, optimization and statistical tools; and (ii) an integrated control-estimation framework for modular systems that incorporates moving horizon estimation into stochastic model predictive control. This potentially transformative research will lead to a deeper understanding of the feasible operating regions for modular energy systems to achieve process intensification and to overcome the control challenges of meeting product quality specifications under the presence of uncertainties and with reduced environmental footprint. By employing the developed methods, the proposed research is expected to accelerate the deployment of the concept of modular manufacturing for energy systems that produce value-added products from low cost methane gas resources with reduced footprint and maximized efficiency. The proposed framework is also flexible and could be adapted to tackle other complex chemical and energy processes.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided advances in process design, intensification and control focusing on modular energy systems. Two main research directions were pursued: (i) an optimization-based approach for process design and intensification; and (ii) an integrated control-estimation framework for modular systems. This transformative research led to a deeper understanding of the feasible operating regions for modular energy systems to achieve process intensification and to overcome the control challenges of meeting product quality specifications, under the presence of uncertainties and with reduced environmental footprint.

In terms of intellectual merit, the main outcome of this project was the systematic development of novel process operability algorithms that enable the investigation of energy systems with reduced footprint, modularization and intensification objectives. The new algorithms developed allow the scientific community and industrial practitioners to simultaneously consider design and control objectives for emerging and/or existing chemical/energy processes. In this sense, processes that are conceptualized and/or modified using the developed methods will use less resources when following the produced modular/intensified design guidelines. Such processes will also be controlled more efficiently and safely after they are built, when compared to using classical approaches of addressing design and control objectives in sequence rather simultaneously. The algorithms developed also enable the prediction of the process steady-state and dynamic behavior, irrespective of the type of controller used (traditional feedback/advanced).

The results of this research have been disseminated via peer-reviewed publications (journals, conference proceedings), open-source software development, and presentations in national, international conferences, and regional meetings. Specifically regarding software development, this project provided user-friendly operability tools in MATLAB and Python that encompass all the process operability algorithms developed throughout the lifetime of this project. In MATLAB, the Process Operability App allows MATLAB users to employ operability algorithms seamlessly without needing to code, with the help of a graphical user interface (GUI). In Python, the opyrability package follows the new guidelines of engineering modeling languages, allowing flexibility and advanced development of process operability studies in a freely available and open-source programming environment. The developed algorithms are ready to use for enhancing industrial chemical process design and control as well incorporation into graduate and undergraduate education.

Regarding application systems, five case studies associated with natural/shale gas utilization were addressed in this project: (i) a catalytic membrane reactor for the direct methane aromatization (DMA-MR) conversion to fuels and chemicals; (ii) a natural gas combined cycle (NGCC) system for combined heat and power generation; (iii) a modular steam methane reforming system (m-SMR) for hydrogen production; (iv) a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) slurry bubble column reactor; and (v) a catalytic membrane reactor for the water gas shift reaction. By focusing on these examples, the successful completion of this research provided a framework to accelerate the deployment of the concept of modular manufacturing for energy systems that produce value-added products from low-cost methane gas resources with reduced footprint and maximized efficiency. The developed process systems framework is flexible and thus could be adapted to tackle a variety of other complex engineering systems, such as biological, mechanical, electrical and power systems.

The main educational and outreach outcomes of this project corresponded to the development of outreach events focused on learning, exploration and recruitment, by employing an interactive gaming environment of 3-D process simulators. In particular, such events were designed to improve the public awareness of the important role that chemical engineers play in producing clean energy and keeping the environment healthy for future generations. To this end, high-school visitations and engineering camp outreach activities were built to engage high-school and undergraduate students including underrepresented groups in STEM, the lay public, and process systems researchers. In such activities, the public knowledge was enhanced by discussing with the participants societal issues such as global climate change, clean energy production, process intensification, energy efficiency, and sustainable utilization of major energy sources. These activities also stimulated the interest of high-school students in pursuing higher-education with a focus on engineering and STEM careers. This project also provided research opportunities for the 3 graduate and 10 undergraduate students involved. In particular, training opportunities were offered to the students in science meetings/conferences and outreach events that included communication, leadership and organizational skills.
